title: The Field and the Knower of the Field
introduction: Chapter 13 of the Bhagavad Gita, Kshetra Kshetrajna Vibhaga Yoga (The Yoga of the Distinction Between the Field and the Knower of the Field), is one of the most analytical, clarifying and philosophically satisfying chapters in the entire scripture. After the emotional peaks of the cosmic vision (Ch. 11) and the loving exposition of devotion (Ch. 12), Krishna now shifts into a precise, almost scientific dissection of reality: what is the 'field' (kshetra = body, matter, nature), who is the 'knower of the field' (kshetrajna = the soul, the conscious witness), how do the two interact, what are the signs of real knowledge, and how does one rise above the field to reach the Supreme. For modern readers — especially those who have read neuroscience, psychology, non-dual teachers, Advaita talks, or who constantly ask 'Who am I really?', 'What is consciousness vs matter?', 'Why do I feel separate from everything?' — this chapter feels like a lucid map that answers almost every existential and metaphysical question in one place. Krishna lists the components of the field, the qualities of the knower, the twenty-four tattvas of Sāṅkhya, the marks of true wisdom, and the ultimate vision of the Supreme Soul present in all. The essence remains perfectly intact: you are not the body-mind-field — you are the eternal knower within it; real knowledge is seeing the distinction clearly and then seeing the one Supreme Knower behind every individual knower. This chapter turns confusion into clarity and suffering into liberation.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |
प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव क्षेत्रं क्षेत्रज्ञमेव च |
एतद्वेदितुमिच्छामि ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं च केशव ||
shlokas.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
prakṛtiṁ puruṣaṁ caiva kṣetraṁ kṣetrajñam eva ca
etad veditum icchāmi jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ ca keśava
shlokas.translation: Arjuna said: O Keshava, I wish to understand prakriti (nature), purusha (the enjoyer), the field (kshetra), the knower of the field (kshetrajna), knowledge, and the object of knowledge.
shlokas.modern: Arjuna asks the foundational question almost every serious seeker eventually asks: What exactly is matter/nature (prakriti)? Who is the conscious self/soul (purusha)? What is this 'field' I experience as my body and world? Who is the real 'I' that knows it? What is true knowledge, and what is ultimately to be known? In 2026 life this is the same hunger behind every deep meditation retreat, every non-dual satsang, every philosophy podcast binge — 'Tell me clearly what is real, what am I, what is this whole experience.' Arjuna is not asking for poetry; he wants a precise map. Krishna is about to deliver one of the clearest ontological breakdowns in spiritual literature.

shlokas.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते |
एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
idaṁ śarīraṁ kaunteya kṣetram ity abhidhīyate
etad yo vetti taṁ prāhuḥ kṣetrajña iti tad-vidaḥ
shlokas.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: This body, O son of Kunti, is called the field, and one who knows this body is called the knower of the field by those who know the truth.
shlokas.modern: Krishna gives the first clear distinction: your body (and by extension the entire material field you experience) is kshetra — the field. The conscious entity inside who knows this field is kshetrajna — the knower. In 2026 terms: the hardware (body, brain, nervous system, senses, environment) is the field; the aware presence that observes it is you, the knower. This is the most fundamental dualism in the Gita — not good vs evil, but matter vs consciousness. Everything that follows builds on this split. This verse is the entry point to real self-inquiry: 'This is the field; who is the one aware of it?'

shlokas.sanskrit:
क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत |
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरज्ञानं यत्तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम ||
shlokas.transliteration:
kṣetrajñaṁ cāpi māṁ viddhi sarva-kṣetreṣu bhārata
kṣetra-kṣetrajñayor jñānaṁ yat taj jñānaṁ mataṁ mama
shlokas.translation: O descendant of Bharata, understand also that I am the knower in all bodies, and to understand this body and its knower is actual knowledge according to Me.
shlokas.modern: Krishna reveals the ultimate twist: not only are you the knower of your own field — I (the Supreme) am the Knower present in every single field/body. True knowledge is knowing both the field and the Knower (individual + Supreme). In 2026 terms: there is not just 'my consciousness' inside my body — there is one universal Consciousness (Krishna) present as the witness in every being. This is the shift from individual soul to Paramatma. Real wisdom is seeing: this body is the field, I am a localized knower, and the same Supreme Knower is in all. This verse collapses solipsism and opens universal vision.

shlokas.sanskrit:
तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक् च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत् |
स च यो यत्प्रभावश्च तत्समासेन मे शृणु ||
shlokas.transliteration:
tat kṣetraṁ yac ca yādṛk ca yad vikāri yataś ca yat
sa ca yo yat-prabhāvaś ca tat samāsena me śṛṇu
shlokas.translation: Now please hear from Me briefly about the field, its nature, its changes, whence it comes, who the knower is, and what his powers are.
shlokas.modern: Krishna promises a concise yet complete explanation: what the field is, what it’s made of, how it changes, where it comes from, who the knower is, and what his powers are. In 2026 language: 'Let me give you the executive summary — body composition, its modifications, origin, the conscious observer, and its capacities.' This verse creates anticipation — Krishna is about to deliver a full metaphysical model in very few verses. This is the Gita’s version of a 'grand unified theory' of existence.

shlokas.sanskrit:
ऋषिभिर्बहुधा गीतं छन्दोभिर्विविधैः पृथक् |
ब्रह्मसूत्रपदैश्चैव हेतुमद्भिर्विनिश्चितैः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
ṛṣibhir bahudhā gītaṁ chandobhir vividhaiḥ pṛthak
brahma-sūtra-padaiś caiva hetumadbhir viniścitaiḥ
shlokas.translation: This knowledge has been described by many sages in various Vedic hymns and especially in the Brahma-sūtra through definitive and logical arguments.
shlokas.modern: Krishna notes that this teaching is not new — it has been sung by many rishis in different Vedic meters and established logically in the Brahma-sūtras. In 2026 terms: 'This is not My personal opinion — it is the perennial philosophy confirmed across scriptures and reasoned inquiry.' This gives authority and universality. The model Krishna is about to give is not sectarian — it is the core understanding of reality shared by the Vedic tradition.

shlokas.sanskrit:
महाभूतान्यहङ्कारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च |
इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च पञ्च चेन्द्रियगोचराः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
mahā-bhūtāny ahaṅkāro buddhir avyaktam eva ca
indriyāṇi daśaikaṁ ca pañca cendriya-gocarāḥ
shlokas.translation: The field is composed of the five great elements, false ego, intelligence, the unmanifest, the ten senses, the mind, and the five objects of the senses.
shlokas.modern: Krishna lists the components of the field: five gross elements (earth, water, fire, air, ether), ego (ahankara), intellect (buddhi), unmanifest prakriti, ten senses (five knowledge + five action), mind, five sense objects (sound, touch, form, taste, smell). In 2026 terms: this is the full inventory of the material-psychic apparatus — matter, ego-identity, thinking faculty, subconscious potential, sensory input/output channels, and the objects they contact. Krishna is giving the complete 'user manual' for the human experience machine. Everything you perceive and identify with is made of these twenty-four items.

shlokas.sanskrit:
इच्छा द्वेषः सुखं दुःखं सङ्घातश्चेतना धृतिः |
एतत्क्षेत्रं समासेन सविकारमुदाहृतम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
icchā dveṣaḥ sukhaṁ duḥkhaṁ saṅghātaś cetanā dhṛtiḥ
etat kṣetraṁ samāsena sa-vikāram udāhṛtam
shlokas.translation: Desire, hatred, happiness, distress, the aggregate (body), consciousness, and conviction — all these constitute the field and its modifications.
shlokas.modern: Krishna adds the experiential layer: desire/aversion, pleasure/pain, the composite body, sentience, and conviction/fixation. These are the dynamic modifications of the field. In 2026 terms: emotions (want/don’t want), hedonic tone, physical embodiment, basic awareness, and belief structures — these are the software running on the hardware listed in v. 6. Together they form the complete 'kshetra' package. Krishna is saying: your entire lived experience — thoughts, feelings, body-sense, identity — is the field. The knower is distinct from all of it.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम् |
आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
amānitvam adambhitvam ahiṁsā kṣāntir ārjavam
ācāryopāsanaṁ śaucaṁ sthairyam ātma-vinigrahaḥ
shlokas.translation: Humility, pridelessness, nonviolence, tolerance, simplicity, approaching a bona fide spiritual master, cleanliness, steadiness, self-control —
shlokas.modern: Krishna now begins the famous list of twenty qualities that constitute real knowledge (jnana): humility (no demand for respect), absence of pretense, nonviolence (physical, verbal, mental), forgiveness, straightforwardness, sincere service to a guru, inner & outer purity, firmness in purpose, mastery over senses/mind. In 2026 life: these are the markers of emotional/spiritual maturity — no ego posturing, no manipulation, harmless speech/action, quick forgiveness, clean intentions, respect for authentic teachers, personal hygiene + mental clarity, reliability, impulse control. Krishna is saying: these attitudes are knowledge itself — they reveal the knower’s detachment from the field.

shlokas.sanskrit:
इन्द्रियार्थेषु वैराग्यमनहङ्कार एव च |
जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
indriyārtheṣu vairāgyam anahaṅkāra eva ca
janma-mṛtyu-jarā-vyādhi-duḥkha-doṣānudarśanam
shlokas.translation: Detachment from sense objects, absence of false ego, perception of the miseries of birth, death, old age, disease, and the defects inherent in them —
shlokas.modern: Continuing the list: dispassion toward sensory pleasures, no 'I am the doer/enjoyer' ego, clear seeing of the inherent suffering in birth, aging, disease, death. In 2026 terms: non-addiction to dopamine hits, no identification with roles/status, constant awareness that the body-mind is a temporary, painful vehicle. These insights keep one unattached to the field. Krishna is teaching realistic detachment — not repression, but clear-eyed recognition of impermanence and pain.

shlokas.sanskrit:
असक्तिरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु |
नित्यं च समचित्तत्वमिष्टानिष्टोपपत्तिषु ||
shlokas.transliteration:
asaktir anabhiṣvaṅgaḥ putra-dāra-gṛhādiṣu
nityaṁ ca sama-cittatvam iṣṭāniṣṭopapattiṣu
shlokas.translation: Non-attachment to children, wife, home, etc., constant even-mindedness in desirable and undesirable situations —
shlokas.modern: More qualities: non-clinging to family/possessions, steady mind whether things go well or badly. In practice: love your family without possessiveness, don’t let success inflate or failure deflate you. This is equanimity in relationships and outcomes. Krishna is describing the emotionally mature devotee — affectionate yet free, balanced in gain/loss. These are the natural fruits of seeing oneself as the knower, not the field.

shlokas.sanskrit:
मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्तिरव्यभिचारिणी |
विविक्तदेशसेवित्वमरतिर्जनसंसदि ||
shlokas.transliteration:
mayi cānanya-yogena bhaktir avyabhicāriṇī
vivikta-deśa-sevitvam aratir jana-saṁsadi
shlokas.translation: Constant, uninterrupted devotion to Me, preference for solitary places, lack of interest in ordinary social gatherings —
shlokas.modern: Unwavering, exclusive devotion to Krishna, love for solitude, disinterest in mundane socializing. In 2026 life: bhakti as the central axis — everything else secondary; comfortable with one’s own company; no addiction to constant social validation or noise. This is the inner turning — the devotee prefers the Divine’s company over crowds. Krishna values this quiet, single-hearted focus.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम् |
एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोऽन्यथा ||
shlokas.transliteration:
adhyātma-jñāna-nityatvaṁ tattva-jñānārtha-darśanam
etaj jñānam iti proktam ajñānaṁ yad ato ’nyathā
shlokas.translation: Perpetual engagement in self-knowledge, seeing the purpose of true knowledge — this is declared to be knowledge, and anything contrary to this is ignorance.
shlokas.modern: Constant focus on spiritual knowledge, clear perception of the goal of truth — this is real jnana. Everything else is ajnana. Krishna defines knowledge not as information accumulation, but as steady self-inquiry and clear vision of ultimate reality. In practice: daily reflection on 'Who am I?', 'What is permanent?', 'What is the goal?' — that is knowledge. Distraction, ego-identification, material fixation — that is ignorance. This verse is the chapter’s pivot — everything before was the field; now Krishna defines what it means to truly know.

shlokas.sanskrit:
ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वामृतमश्नुते |
अनादिमत्परं ब्रह्म न सत्तन्नासदुच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
jñeyaṁ yat tat pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvāmṛtam aśnute
anādimat paraṁ brahma na sat tan nāsad ucyate
shlokas.translation: I shall now explain that which is to be known, by knowing which one tastes the nectar of immortality. It is the beginningless Supreme Brahman, said to be neither existent nor non-existent.
shlokas.modern: Krishna now describes the object of knowledge — the imperishable Brahman, beginningless, beyond being/non-being — knowing which brings immortality. In 2026 terms: the ultimate reality is not 'something' that exists or 'nothing' that doesn’t — it is prior to both categories. This is classic non-dual language — Brahman is the ground of being, not an object within being. Knowing It (not just intellectually) ends death (identification with the perishable field). This verse shifts from the field to the ultimate Knower.

shlokas.sanskrit:
सर्वतः पाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम् |
सर्वतः श्रुतिमल्लोके सर्वमावृत्य तिष्ठति ||
shlokas.transliteration:
sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādaṁ tat sarvato ’kṣi-śiro-mukham
sarvataḥ śrutimal loke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati
shlokas.translation: Everywhere are His hands and legs, His eyes, heads and faces, and He hears everything. In this way the Supersoul exists pervading everything.
shlokas.modern: The Supreme has hands/feet, eyes/heads/faces, ears everywhere — pervading all. This is the immanent aspect of Brahman — not a distant void, but the all-pervading consciousness that is the seeing, hearing, acting principle in every being. In practice: every hand that helps, every eye that sees, every ear that listens — is animated by the same Supreme. This ends separation. Brahman is not 'out there' — It is the aware presence behind every experience.

shlokas.sanskrit:
सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम् |
असक्तं सर्वभृच्चैव निर्गुणं गुणभोक्तृ च ||
shlokas.transliteration:
sarvendriya-guṇābhāsaṁ sarvendriya-vivarjitam
asaktaṁ sarva-bhṛc caiva nirguṇaṁ guṇa-bhoktṛ ca
shlokas.translation: The Supersoul is the original source of all senses, yet He is without senses. He is unattached, yet He is the maintainer of all living entities. He transcends the modes of nature, and at the same time He is the master of all modes.
shlokas.modern: Brahman appears as all senses yet has no senses; unattached yet supports all; beyond gunas yet enjoys them. This is the paradox of the Absolute — immanent and transcendent. In 2026 terms: consciousness enables seeing/hearing/touching yet is not limited by organs; sustains all life yet is not entangled; is prior to sattva/rajas/tamas yet expresses through them. This verse destroys anthropomorphic and deistic ideas — the Supreme is both within and beyond every experience.

shlokas.sanskrit:
बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च |
सूक्ष्मत्वात्तदविज्ञेयं दूरस्थं चान्तिके च तत् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
bahir antaś ca bhūtānām acaraṁ caram eva ca
sūkṣmatvāt tad avijñeyaṁ dūra-sthaṁ cāntike ca tat
shlokas.translation: The Supreme Truth exists both outside and inside all living beings, both moving and non-moving. Because He is subtle, He is beyond the power of the material senses to perceive or understand. Although far away, He is also near to all.
shlokas.modern: The Divine is inside/outside all beings, in moving/non-moving things; too subtle for senses/mind to grasp; simultaneously distant and near. This is the classic near-far, inside-outside paradox of the Absolute. In practice: God is closer than your own breath yet cannot be captured by thought or microscope. This ends both atheism ('God is nowhere') and crude theism ('God is only far away'). The Supreme is intimately present yet utterly ungraspable — this is the mystery that devotion embraces.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम् |
भूतभर्तृ च तज्ज्ञेयं ग्रसिष्णु प्रभविष्णु च ||
shlokas.transliteration:
avibhaktaṁ ca bhūteṣu vibhaktam iva ca sthitam
bhūta-bhartṛ ca taj jñeyaṁ grasiṣṇu prabhaviṣṇu ca
shlokas.translation: Although undivided, the Supreme appears divided among beings. He is to be known as the supporter of beings; He devours and generates them.
shlokas.modern: Undivided yet appears divided in beings; supports all, destroys and creates them. This is the simultaneous unity and diversity. In practice: one Consciousness appears as many souls; the same Self sustains, dissolves, and recreates everything. This is the vision of non-duality in a devotional key — the One playing as many. Krishna is showing the cosmic dance: unity behind multiplicity, destruction and creation as His play.

shlokas.sanskrit:
ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते |
ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानगम्यं हृदि सर्वस्य विष्ठितम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
jyotiṣām api taj jyotis tamasaḥ param ucyate
jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ jñāna-gamyaṁ hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam
shlokas.translation: He is the light of all lights and is beyond the darkness of ignorance. He is knowledge, He is the object of knowledge, and He is the goal of knowledge. He is situated in everyone’s heart.
shlokas.modern: The Supreme is the light behind all lights, beyond darkness; He is knowledge, the known, and the knowable — seated in every heart. This is one of the most luminous verses in the Gita. In practice: every insight, every awakening, every candle of awareness is lit by Him. He is both the subject and object of all knowing, and He resides right here in your own heart. This ends the search 'out there' — turn inward. The Divine is the innermost light, the goal of every quest. This verse is pure revelation — God is closer than close.

shlokas.sanskrit:
इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः |
मद्भक्त एतद्विज्ञाय मद्भावायोपपद्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
iti kṣetraṁ tathā jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ coktaṁ samāsataḥ
mad-bhakta etad vijñāya mad-bhāvāyopapadyate
shlokas.translation: Thus the field, knowledge, and the knowable have been summarily described by Me. Only My devotee who understands this becomes fit to attain My nature.
shlokas.modern: Krishna summarizes: field, knowledge, object of knowledge — all explained. My devotee who knows this enters My being/nature. This is the chapter’s hinge — knowledge culminates in devotion. In practice: understanding the distinction (field vs knower) and seeing the Supreme Knower in all leads to bhakti — loving union. Intellectual clarity ripens into love. Krishna is saying: the purpose of this analysis is not dry philosophy — it is to deepen love for Me. The devotee who gets this becomes qualified for the highest realization.

shlokas.sanskrit:
प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव विद्ध्यनादि उभावपि |
विकारांश्च गुणांश्चैव विद्धि प्रकृतिसम्भवान् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
prakṛtiṁ puruṣaṁ caiva viddhy anādi ubhāv api
vikārāṁś ca guṇāṁś caiva viddhi prakṛti-sambhavān
shlokas.translation: Know that both material nature and the living entity are without beginning. Know also that transformations and the modes of matter are produced by material nature.
shlokas.modern: Both prakriti (nature) and purusha (soul) are beginningless. The modifications and gunas arise from prakriti. This establishes eternal duality — matter and spirit have no beginning in time. In 2026 terms: consciousness and matter are co-eternal principles — neither creates the other. Change (vikara) and qualities (gunas) belong to matter only. This verse corrects both materialist reductionism (consciousness emerges from matter) and certain idealisms (matter is illusion). Krishna gives the classical Sāṅkhya foundation — two eternal categories.

shlokas.sanskrit:
कार्यकारणकर्तृत्वे हेतुः प्रकृतिरुच्यते |
पुरुषः सुखदुःखानां भोक्तृत्वे हेतुरुच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
kārya-kāraṇa-kartṛtve hetuḥ prakṛtir ucyate
puruṣaḥ sukha-duḥkhānāṁ bhoktṛtve hetur ucyate
shlokas.translation: Nature is said to be the cause of all material causes and effects, whereas the living entity is the cause of the experience of pleasure and pain.
shlokas.modern: Prakriti is responsible for cause-effect chains (material creation); purusha experiences pleasure/pain. In practice: matter produces the machinery of action and reaction; the soul is the enjoyer/sufferer. This clarifies responsibility — nature runs the show, consciousness watches and feels. This verse ends blame — your suffering is not 'your fault'; it is the field’s play. The soul identifies with it and suffers. Liberation is disidentification.

shlokas.sanskrit:
पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान्गुणान् |
कारणं गुणसङ्गोऽस्य सदसद्योनिजन्मसु ||
shlokas.transliteration:
puruṣaḥ prakṛti-stho hi bhuṅkte prakṛti-jān guṇān
kāraṇaṁ guṇa-saṅgo ’sya sad-asad-yoni-janmasu
shlokas.translation: The living entity in material nature follows the ways of life, enjoying the three modes of nature. This is due to his association with that material nature. Thus he meets with good and evil among various species.
shlokas.modern: The soul in nature experiences the gunas born of nature. Attachment to gunas causes birth in higher/lower species. In 2026 terms: identification with sattva/rajas/tamas creates the karmic momentum that determines next embodiment. The soul is neutral — it is the association/identification that binds. This verse explains reincarnation mechanistically — no moralistic punishment, just consequence of attachment. Freedom comes from detachment from the gunas.

shlokas.sanskrit:
उपद्रष्टानुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः |
परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन्पुरुषः परः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
upadraṣṭānumantā ca bhartā bhoktā maheśvaraḥ
paramātmeti cāpy ukto dehe ’smin puruṣaḥ paraḥ
shlokas.translation: Yet in this body there is also a transcendental, eternal enjoyer, who is the Lord, the supreme proprietor, the overseer, the witness, the permitter, the sustainer, and the Supersoul.
shlokas.modern: In this very body is the Supreme — the overseer, witness, permitter, supporter, experiencer, great Lord, Paramatma. Krishna reveals the third presence: besides field and individual knower, there is the Supreme Knower in every heart. In practice: you are the localized knower, but Paramatma is the universal witness in you. This ends solipsism — there is one Supreme Consciousness present in all. This verse is the bridge to non-dual realization within a devotional framework.

shlokas.sanskrit:
य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह |
सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
ya evaṁ vetti puruṣaṁ prakṛtiṁ ca guṇaiḥ saha
sarvathā vartamāno ’pi na sa bhūyo ’bhijāyate
shlokas.translation: One who knows the individual soul, nature, and the modes of nature in this way is never reborn, no matter how he lives.
shlokas.modern: Whoever truly understands purusha, prakriti and the gunas is never born again — whatever his external life. This is the liberating knowledge. In practice: correct ontological understanding (soul ≠ body, gunas belong to nature) ends rebirth — even if one appears ordinary. This verse promises jivanmukti — liberation while living. Krishna is saying: the truth sets you free instantly — not after death, not after renunciation, but right now through right knowledge.

shlokas.sanskrit:
ध्यानेनात्मनि पश्यन्ति केचिदात्मानमात्मना |
अन्ये साङ्ख्येन योगेन कर्मयोगेन चापरे ||
shlokas.transliteration:
dhyānenātmani paśyanti kecid ātmānam ātmanā
anye sāṅkhyena yogena karma-yogena cāpare
shlokas.translation: Some perceive the Self within the self by meditation; others by the path of knowledge (Sāṅkhya), and still others by the path of work (karma yoga).
shlokas.modern: Different paths to realization: meditation (dhyana), analytical knowledge (Sāṅkhya), selfless action (karma yoga). Krishna is inclusive — multiple valid approaches. In 2026 terms: contemplative practice, philosophical inquiry, dedicated work — all can lead to the same truth. This removes sectarianism — the goal is seeing the distinction between field and knower. Different temperaments take different roads.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अन्ये त्वेवमजानन्तः श्रुत्वान्येभ्य उपासते |
तेऽपि चातितरन्त्येव मृत्युं श्रुतिपरायणाः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
anye tv evam ajānantaḥ śrutvānyebhya upāsate
te ’pi cātitaranty eva mṛtyuṁ śruti-parāyaṇāḥ
shlokas.translation: Others, who do not know these paths, begin to worship the Supreme by hearing from others. Even they, by taking shelter of hearing, can cross beyond birth and death.
shlokas.modern: Even those who don’t know the paths — if they hear from others and take refuge in hearing — they too transcend death. This is the power of shravana (hearing) and faith. In practice: you don’t need to be a meditator, philosopher or karma yogi — simply listen sincerely to realized souls and trust. This is the easiest entry for most people in Kali Yuga. Krishna is saying: even beginners who hear and believe can be liberated. This verse is pure grace — no one is excluded.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यावत्सञ्जायते किञ्चित्सत्त्वं स्थावरजङ्गमम् |
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञसंयोगात्तद्विद्धि भरतर्षभ ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yāvat sañjāyate kiñcit sattvaṁ sthāvara-jaṅgamam
kṣetra-kṣetrajña-saṁyogāt tad viddhi bharatarṣabha
shlokas.translation: O best of the Bharatas, whatever you see in existence — moving or unmoving — is only the combination of the field and the knower of the field.
shlokas.modern: Everything that exists — moving or still — is just the union of kshetra and kshetrajna. This is the final ontological statement. In practice: no object, no creature, no phenomenon is anything other than matter + consciousness. This ends mystery — the entire universe is field + knower interplay. Krishna is giving the simplest, most universal map: look anywhere, see only these two. This verse collapses all complexity into one clear insight.

shlokas.sanskrit:
समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम् |
न हिनस्त्यात्मनात्मानं ततो याति परां गतिम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
samaṁ paśyan hi sarvatra samavasthitam īśvaram
na hinasty ātmanātmānaṁ tato yāti parāṁ gatim
shlokas.translation: One who sees the Supreme Lord equally present in all beings never degrades himself — thus he reaches the supreme destination.
shlokas.modern: Whoever sees the same Supreme Lord equally in all beings does not harm himself and reaches the highest goal. This is the vision of equality. In practice: recognizing Paramatma in every heart ends violence, envy, superiority — because hurting another is hurting the same Self. This vision purifies and liberates. Krishna is saying: see Me everywhere → self-respect + universal respect → liberation. This is the ethical fruit of metaphysical knowledge.

shlokas.sanskrit:
प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः |
यः पश्यति तथात्मानमकर्तारं स पश्यति ||
shlokas.transliteration:
prakṛtyaiva ca karmāṇi kriyamāṇāni sarvaśaḥ
yaḥ paśyati tathātmānam akartāraṁ sa paśyati
shlokas.translation: One who sees that all actions are performed by material nature and that the self is not the doer — he truly sees.
shlokas.modern: Seeing that all actions are done by prakriti and the self is not the doer — that is real seeing. This is the classic karma yoga realization. In practice: ego claims 'I did it' — wisdom sees nature acting through the body-mind. This ends pride and guilt. Krishna is teaching radical non-doership — actions happen, but 'I' am the witness, not the agent. This insight liberates from karma bondage.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति |
तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yadā bhūta-pṛthag-bhāvam eka-stham anupaśyati
tata eva ca vistāraṁ brahma sampadyate tadā
shlokas.translation: When a person sees that all diversity is situated in one unity and that everything expands from that unity — at that time he attains Brahman.
shlokas.modern: Seeing multiplicity resting in unity, and all expansion coming from that unity — then one attains Brahman. This is the non-dual realization. In practice: behind every separate form is the one Brahman expanding into many. Seeing this unity brings union with Brahman. Krishna is describing the moment of non-dual awakening — diversity is appearance; reality is one. This is the goal of knowledge — seeing the One in the many.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अनादित्वान्निर्गुणत्वात्परमात्मायमव्ययः |
शरीरस्थोऽपि कौन्तेय न करोति न लिप्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
anāditvān nirguṇatvāt paramātmāyam avyayaḥ
śarīra-stho ’pi kaunteya na karoti na lipyate
shlokas.translation: Because the Supersoul is beginningless and transcendental to material attributes, O son of Kunti, even though situated in the body, He neither acts nor is tainted by actions.
shlokas.modern: Paramatma is beginningless, beyond gunas, imperishable — even in the body, He neither acts nor is affected by actions. This is the pure witness nature. In practice: the Supreme Soul in you is never the doer, never stained by karma. This ends guilt and pride forever — the real You (Paramatma) is untouched. Krishna is giving the ultimate detachment — identify with the witness, not the actor. This is liberation while living.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते |
सर्वत्रावस्थितो देहे तथात्मा नोपलिप्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yathā sarva-gataṁ saukṣmyād ākāśaṁ nopalipyate
sarvatrāvasthito dehe tathātmā nopalipyate
shlokas.translation: As the all-pervading sky is not contaminated because of its subtlety, similarly the soul, though present in the body, is not contaminated.
shlokas.modern: Just as space pervades everything yet remains untouched by anything, the soul in the body remains pure. This is the classic space analogy for the Self. In practice: no matter what happens in/around the body — pollution, pleasure, pain — the real You is like space: present yet unstained. This verse brings radical purity — nothing can touch the Self. Krishna is giving the ultimate non-identification teaching.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः |
क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yathā prakāśayaty ekaḥ kṛtsnaṁ lokam imaṁ raviḥ
kṣetraṁ kṣetrī tathā kṛtsnaṁ prakāśayati bhārata
shlokas.translation: O son of Bharata, as the sun alone illuminates the entire universe, similarly the soul within the body illuminates the entire field of activities.
shlokas.modern: Just as one sun lights the whole world, the knower illuminates the whole field. This is the sun analogy for consciousness. In practice: the body-mind-world is dark until consciousness lights it — like sunlight revealing objects. The knower is the light by which everything is known. This verse establishes the primacy of consciousness — matter is inert without it. Krishna is giving another powerful pointer to the Self as pure awareness.

shlokas.sanskrit:
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवमन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा |
भूतप्रकृतिमोक्षं च ये विदुर्यान्ति ते परम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
kṣetra-kṣetrajñayor evam antaraṁ jñāna-cakṣuṣā
bhūta-prakṛti-mokṣaṁ ca ye vidur yānti te param
shlokas.translation: Those who see with the eye of knowledge the distinction between the field and the knower of the field, and also the liberation of the living entity from material nature — they attain the Supreme.
shlokas.modern: Whoever sees clearly the difference between field and knower, and understands liberation from material nature — they reach the Supreme. This is the chapter’s final promise. In practice: correct discrimination (viveka) between body/mind (field) and consciousness (knower) + realization of freedom from prakriti = liberation. Krishna is saying: this knowledge itself is moksha. The one who truly understands this distinction attains Paramatma. This verse is the culmination — knowledge becomes liberation when it is direct and liberating insight.
